revision.text:
{{Redirect|Personal attack|the policy on Wikipedia|Wikipedia:No personal attacks}} {{Italic title}} [[Image:Graham's_Hierarchy_of_Disagreement-en.svg|thumb|right|375px|[[Paul Graham (computer programmer)|Paul Graham]]'s Hierarchy of Disagreement lists ad hominem as the second lowest type of argument in a disagreement.]] '''''Ad hominem''''' ([[Latin]] for "to the person"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ad%20hominem|title=Ad hominem|work=[[Merriam-Webster]]|publisher=Merriam-Webster, Incorporated|accessdate=19 February 2013}}</ref>), short for '''''argumentum ad hominem''''', is a fallacious argumentative strategy whereby genuine discussion of the topic at hand is avoided by instead attacking the character, motive, or other attribute of the person making the argument, or persons associated with the argument, rather than attacking the substance of the argument itself.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aphilosopher.files.wordpress.com/2010/09/42-fallacies.pdf |title=42 Fallacies: Ad Hominem |author=Dr. Michael C. Labossiere |date=2002–2010 |page=2 |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref> The terms ''ad mulierem''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Olivesi|first=Aurélie|date=2010-04-05|title=L’interrogation sur la compétence politique en 2007 : une question de genre ?|url=https://journals.openedition.org/quaderni/486|journal=Quaderni|language=fr|issue=72|pages=59–74|doi=10.4000/quaderni.486|issn=0987-1381}}</ref> and ''ad feminam''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sommers|first=Christina|date=March 1991|title=ARGUMENTUM AD FEMINAM|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1467-9833.1991.tb00016.x|journal=Journal of Social Philosophy|language=en|volume=22|issue=1|pages=5–19|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9833.1991.tb00016.x|issn=0047-2786}}</ref> have been used specifically when the person receiving the criticism is female.
However, its original meaning was an argument "calculated to appeal to the person addressed more than to impartial reason".<ref>Fowler, H. W. (1926), ''A Dictionary of Modern English Usage'' (under ''Technical Terms'')</ref>
Fallacious ''ad hominem'' reasoning is categorized among [[informal fallacy|informal fallacies]],<ref name="one">{{cite book |author=[[Doug Walton|Walton, Douglas]] |title=Informal Logic: A Pragmatic Approach |year=2008 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |page=190}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Bowell|first1=Tracy|last2=Kemp|first2=Gary|title=Critical Thinking: A Concise Guide|year=2010|publisher=Routledge|location=Abingdon, Oxon|isbn=0-415-47183-4|pages=210–213}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|first=Irving M.|last=Copi|title=Informal Logic|isbn=0-02-324940-4|publisher=Macmillan|year=1986|pages=112–113}}</ref> more precisely as a [[genetic fallacy]], a subcategory of [[fallacies of irrelevance]].
== Types == {{See also|List of fallacies}}
===''Tu quoque''=== {{Main|Tu quoque}} ''Ad hominem tu quoque'' (literally: "You also") refers to a claim that the source making the argument has spoken or acted in a way inconsistent with the argument. In particular, if Source A criticizes the actions of Source B, a ''tu quoque'' response is that Source A has acted in the same way. This argument is invalid because it does not disprove the premise; if the premise is true then Source A may be a [[hypocrite]], but this does not make the statement less credible from a logical perspective. Indeed, Source A may be in a position to provide personal testimony to support the argument.
For example, a father may tell his son not to start smoking as he will regret it when he is older, and the son may point out that his father is or was a smoker. This does not alter the fact that his son may regret smoking when he is older.
===Circumstantial=== {{Main|Bulverism}} ''Circumstantial ad hominem'' points out that someone is in circumstances such that they are disposed to take a particular position. It constitutes an attack on the bias of a source. This is fallacious because a disposition to make a certain argument does not make the argument invalid; this overlaps with the [[genetic fallacy]] (an argument that a claim is incorrect due to its source).<ref name="Walton (1998) p18-21">{{cite book |last=Walton |first=Douglas |title=Ad Hominem Arguments |publisher=University of Alabama Press |year=1998 |isbn=0-8173-0922-5 |pages=18–21}}</ref>
The circumstantial fallacy does not apply where the source is taking a position by using a logical argument based solely on premises that are generally accepted. Where the source seeks to convince an audience of the truth of a premise by a claim of authority or by personal observation, observation of their circumstances may reduce the evidentiary weight of the claims, sometimes to zero.<ref name="Fallacy Files">{{cite web |url=http://www.fallacyfiles.org/adhomine.html |title=Argumentum ad Hominem |accessdate=2007-09-10 |work=Fallacy Files |last=Curtis |first=Gary N.| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070920193815/http://www.fallacyfiles.org/adhomine.html| archivedate= 20 September 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
'''Examples''':
# [[Mandy Rice-Davies]]'s famous testimony during the [[Profumo Affair]], "He would [say that], wouldn't he?", is an example of a valid circumstantial argument. Her point was that a man in a prominent position, accused of an affair with a [[callgirl]], would deny the claim whether it was true or false. His denial, in itself, provides little evidence against the claim of an affair.
However, this argument is valid only insofar as it devalues the denial; it does ''not'' strengthen the original claim. To construe invalid evidence of the denial as valid evidence of the original claim is fallacious (on several different bases, including that of ''argumentum ad hominem'' and ''appeal to emotions''); however likely the man in question would be to deny an affair that did in fact happen, he is even more likely to deny an affair that never happened. (For example, inferring guilt from a denial{{snd}}or, less starkly, excessive devaluation of a denial{{snd}}is a very common feature in [[Conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]], [[witch-hunt]]s, [[show trials]], [[struggle sessions]], and other coercive circumstances in which the person targeted is presumed guilty.)
# Glassner suggests that Bennett is somehow unqualified to criticize rap music because of positions Bennett has taken on other issues. However wrong Bennett may or may not have been on other issues, that does not mean that his criticisms of rap were mistaken.<ref name="Fallacy Files">{{cite web |url=http://www.fallacyfiles.org/adhomine.html |title=Argumentum ad Hominem |accessdate=2007-09-10 |work=Fallacy Files |last=Curtis |first=Gary N.| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070920193815/http://www.fallacyfiles.org/adhomine.html| archivedate= 20 September 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Guilt by association=== {{Main|Association fallacy}} Guilt by association can sometimes also be a type of ''ad hominem'' fallacy if the argument attacks a source because of the similarity between the views of someone making an argument and other proponents of the argument.<ref name="Walton (1998) p18-21"/>
This form of the argument is as follows: # Source S makes claim C. # Group G, which is currently viewed negatively by the recipient, also makes claim C. # Therefore, source S is viewed by the recipient of the claim as associated to the group G and inherits how negatively viewed it is.
An example of this fallacy could be "My opponent for office just received an endorsement from the Puppy Haters Association. Is that the sort of person you would want to vote for?"
== Non-fallacious reasoning == When a statement is challenged by making an ''ad hominem'' attack on its author, it is important to draw a distinction between whether the statement in question was ''an argument'' or ''a statement of fact'' (''testimony''). In the latter case the issues of the credibility of the person making the statement may be crucial.<ref name="Fallacy Files"/>
== Criticism as a fallacy ==
[[Doug Walton]], Canadian academic and author, has argued that ''ad hominem'' reasoning is not always fallacious, and that in some instances, questions of personal conduct, character, motives, etc., are legitimate and relevant to the issue,<ref>{{cite book |author=Walton, Douglas |title=Informal Logic: A Pragmatic Approach |year=2008 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |page=170}}</ref> as when it directly involves hypocrisy, or actions contradicting the subject's words.
The philosopher [[Charles Taylor (philosopher)|Charles Taylor]] has argued that ''ad hominem'' reasoning (discussing facts about the speaker or author relative to the value of his statements) is essential to understanding certain moral issues due to the connection between individual persons and morality (or moral claims), and contrasts this sort of reasoning with the [[apodicticity|apodictic]] reasoning (involving facts beyond dispute or clearly established) of philosophical naturalism.<ref name=Taylor>{{cite book |authorlink=Charles Taylor (philosopher) |last=Taylor |first=Charles |title=Philosophical Arguments |year=1995 |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=9780674664760 |pages=34–60 |url=https://books.google.com.mx/books?id=iqtLAsIBZ2sC&pg=PA34&lpg=PA34&dq=explanation+and+practical+reason+charles+taylor&source=bl&ots=NULkg3WL_-&sig=BaEwQ_OXdRBysmVeQVkM4uKJ2s8&hl=es&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false |chapter=Explanation and Practical Reason}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Logic|Philosophy}} {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * "[[And you are lynching Negroes]]" * [[Appeal to authority]] * [[Appeal to emotion]] * [[Appeal to motive]] * [[Association fallacy]] * [[Bulverism]] * [[Character assassination]] * [[Discrediting tactic]] * [[Fair Game (Scientology)]] * [[Fake news]] * [[Fundamental attribution error]] * [[Gaslighting]] * [[Hostile witness]] * [[Negative campaigning]] * [[Poisoning the well]] * [[Race card]] * [[Red herring]] * [[Reputation]] * [[Shooting the messenger]] * [[Smear campaign]] * [[Straw man]] * [[Tone policing]] * ''[[The Art of Being Right]]'' * [[Tu quoque]] * [[Whataboutism]] {{Div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * {{Cite book | last = Hurley | first = Patrick | title = A Concise Introduction to Logic |edition=7th | publisher = Wadsworth | year = 2000 | pages = 125–128, 182 | isbn = 0-534-52006-5 }} * {{Cite book |last=Copi |first=Irving M. |last2=Cohen |first2=Carl |title=Introduction to Logic |edition=8th |pages=97–100}} * {{Cite book |author=[[Doug Walton|Walton, Douglas]] |title=Ad Hominem Arguments |year=1998 |location=Tuscaloosa |publisher=University Alabama Press}}
==External links== {{Wiktionary|ad hominem}} *{{PhilPapers|search|ad_hominem}} * [http://www.nizkor.org/features/fallacies/ad-hominem.html Nizkor.org: Fallacy: Ad Hominem]. * [http://www.nizkor.org/features/fallacies/circumstantial-ad-hominem.html Nizkor.org: Fallacy: Circumstantial Ad Hominem]. * [http://philosophy.lander.edu/logic/person.html Argumentum Ad Hominem] * {{cite web|url= http://www.dougwalton.ca/papers%20in%20pdf/01roots.pdf |title=University of Winnipeg: Argumentation Schemes and Historical Origins of the Circumstantial Ad Hominen Argument }} {{small|(70.2 KB)}} * [http://www.logicalfallacies.info/relevance/ad-hominem/ Logical Fallacies: Ad Hominem]

{{unreferenced|date=January 2008}}
'''Aging''' is a process by which an [[Work of art|art]]work, typically a [[painting]] or [[sculpture]], is made to appear old. It is meant to emulate the natural deterioration that can occur over many decades or centuries.
Paintings deteriorate over time because they are created using essentially incompatible materials, with each having a different reaction to the changes in the environment, including light, temperature and [[relative humidity]].
An oil painting consists of several layers, comprising the base [[canvas]], a layer of [[gesso]] base coat, several layers of the [[oil paint|oil-based paint]] and then several coats of [[varnish]] to protect the paint surface. With many different materials, it is understandable that each layer may dry at different rates and will also absorb and release moisture at different rates. When this occurs, expansion and contraction of the painting will result in a crazing of the varnish surface. This pattern of small cracks is known as [[craquelure]]. Along with the darkening or yellowing of the varnish surface, it is this visual representation of the cracking that is typically the primary indicator of ageing.
The purpose for artificially ageing is to create a finished product that accurately reflects an era or is consistent with the environment (usually period) into which it is to be placed.
== See also == *[[Art conservation and restoration]] *[[Art forgery]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aged Artwork}} {{Cultural Conservation-Restoration |state=expanded}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Person | name = Anne Maynard | image = Ann Lady Maynard by George Willison.jpg | image_size = | caption = "in Turkish Dress" in 1771 | birth_name = Anne Parsons | birth_date = c.1735 | birth_place = | death_date = 1814/5 | death_place = [[Paris]] | death_cause = | residence = | other_names = Nancy Parsons; Mrs Horton | known_for = successful courtesan | education = | spouse = [[Viscount Maynard|Charles Maynard, second Viscount Maynard]] | partner = [[William Petty, second earl of Shelburne|Earl of Shelburne]], Arnold Nesbitt, [[Richard Rigby]], [[Augustus FitzRoy, 3rd Duke of Grafton]], [[John Sackville, 3rd Duke of Dorset]], [[Francis Russell, 5th Duke of Bedford]] | children = | footnotes = | nationality = [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] }}
'''Anne Maynard''' or '''Anne, Viscountess Maynard; Anne Parsons; Nancy Parsons; Nancy Maynard; Mrs Horton''' (c. 1735 – 1814/5) was a [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] successful courtesan and political mistress. She was de facto first lady, entertaining guests for her lover, the [[First Minister]] ([[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]]).
==Life== Her birth is estimated to be 1735 and one account says that her father was a tailor in [[Bond Street]] in London. She is thought to have first been a prostitute. She is said to have gone to Jamaica with a man called Horton or Houghton and according to some accounts they married and he may have died. When she returned she used a married name of "Mrs Horton".<ref name=odnb/>
In 1760 she was a high-class prostitute to members of the aristocracy including the [[William Petty, second earl of Shelburne|Earl of Shelburne]], a contractor Arnold Nesbitt, and [[Richard Rigby]] who was a [[Privy Council]] member.<ref name=odnb/>
In 1764, she had a scandalous affair with [[Augustus FitzRoy, 3rd Duke of Grafton]] whilst his wife [[Anne FitzPatrick]] was pregnant.<ref>Matthew Kilburn, ‘Fitzpatrick , Anne, countess of Upper Ossory [other married name Anne FitzRoy, duchess of Grafton] (1737/8–1804)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, Oct 2008 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/88658, accessed 23 March 2017]
</ref> FitzRoy kept Parsons at his town house and took her to the opera. This brazen lack of convention offended society's standards. Parsons was openly living on the duke's estates and meanwhile the Duke became [[Secretary of State]] in 1765.
Parsons was entertaining his guests and they reported on her informed conversation. In 1767 the Duke became [[first minister]] and she had the influence, if not the position, of a [[First Lady]] in her country. Richard Rigby used her influence to turn opinions against the Duke's wife. There was further gossip when the Duchess of Grafton become pregnant by her lover, the [[John FitzPatrick, 2nd Earl of Upper Ossory|Earl of Upper Ossory]], she and the Duke were divorced by Act of Parliament on the 23 March 1769.<ref name=odnbfitz>Peter Durrant, ‘FitzRoy, Augustus Henry, third duke of Grafton (1735–1811)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Oct 2008 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/9628, accessed 14 Feb 2017]</ref> Parsons may have become the First Minister's wife had he not discovered that Parsons was having an affair with [[John Sackville, 3rd Duke of Dorset]].<ref name=odnb>A. A. Hanham, ‘Parsons, Anne [Nancy] married name Anne Maynard, Viscountess Maynard] (c.1735–1814/15)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, May 2005 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/75617, accessed 14 Feb 2017]</ref>
[[file:Mrs. Horton, Later Viscountess Maynard by Joshua Reynolds.jpg|thumb|left|''Mrs. Horton, Later Viscountess Maynard'' by [[Joshua Reynolds]] ]]
Three months later, on 24 June 1769, the Duke married Elizabeth Wrottesley (1 November 1745{{snd}}25 May 1822), daughter of the [[Sir Richard Wrottesley, 7th Baronet|Reverend Sir Richard Wrottesley]], [[Dean of Worcester]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Hellicar|1978|p=28}}</ref>
In around 1770 she was painted by [[Joshua Reynolds]]. Again in 1771 she was painted by [[George Willison (artist)|George Willison]] in "Turkish Dress". That painting is now in [[Yale Centre for British Art]].<ref name=baetjer>{{cite book|author1=Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.)|author2=Katharine Baetjer|title=British Paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1575-1875|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FZzL3ey6gDYC&pg=PA76|year=2009|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|isbn=978-1-58839-348-7|pages=76–77}}</ref>
She and Sackville spent the next six/seven years together until 1706 when Parsons attracted the attention of [[Viscount Maynard|Charles Maynard, second Viscount Maynard]]. At this point Maynard was 23 and Parsons was maybe ten years older.<ref name=baetjer/> The two married on 24 September 1776 in London before visiting Italy where they had difficulty entering the Royal court because of their history.<ref name=odnb/>
In 1784 the two created a [[menage a trois]] with the teenage [[Francis Russell, 5th Duke of Bedford]]. This liaison was with Russell grandmother's approval and it continued until 1787. Parsons was received by minor members of the Royal Family and spent the remainder of her life solo in Italy and France.<ref name=odnb/> She died near Paris in 1814 or 1815.<ref name=baetjer/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Parsons, Anne}} [[Category:1730s births]] [[Category:1810s deaths]] [[Category:Courtesans]] [[Category:British viscountesses]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox Organization |name = BioCity Nottingham |image = File:Bio City Nottingham (2) - geograph.org.uk - 948646.jpg |size = |caption = Biocity buildings |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = September 2003 |status = Science park |purpose = Bioscience innovation |location = Pennyfoot Street, Nottingham, NG1 1GF |region_served = UK |membership = 70 companies |leader_title = Chief Executive |leader_name = Dr Glenn Crocker |main_organ = BioCity Board (Chairman – Dr Louis Nisbet) |parent_organization = |affiliations = [[Nottingham Trent University]], [[University of Nottingham]], |budget = |website = [http://www.biocity.co.uk BioCity] }}
'''BioCity Nottingham''' is a bioscience [[science park]] in central [[Nottingham]] in the United Kingdom. It is the UK's largest bioscience innovation and incubation centre.
==History== In 2002, laboratories and office space were donated to [[Nottingham Trent University]] by BASF. Biocity was founded in September 2003 by the University of Nottingham, Nottingham Trent University (NTU) and the [[East Midlands Development Agency]] (which was based close to BioCity).
Biocity's premises were developed from the building donated by BASF. Phase 1 was completed in March 2004, providing {{convert|36000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of space, then Phase 2 in March 2006 provided {{convert|24000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. When Phase 3 of the development was completed in October 2008, with {{convert|45000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}, funding from emda also finished.
===Background=== Nottingham has long been an important centre for bioscience research, principally through work done at the University of Nottingham, Nottingham Trent University and by [[Boots UK|Boots]], Britain's largest retail [[pharmacy]] company, which is based in [[Dunkirk, Nottingham|Dunkirk]]/[[Beeston, Nottinghamshire|Beeston]]. Although Boots no longer engages in drug discovery, [[Ibuprofen]] (iso-butyl-propanoic-phenolic acid) was created by Boots scientists in Nottingham.<ref>[http://www.york.ac.uk/enterprise/cetle/resources/WRCE/Case%20Study%20-%20Boots%20the%20Chemist.pdf Boots ibuprofen project] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001172448/http://www.york.ac.uk/enterprise/cetle/resources/WRCE/Case%20Study%20-%20Boots%20the%20Chemist.pdf |date=1 October 2012 }}</ref> In March 2005 Nottingham was named as a Science City; the other 5 Science Cities were [[Birmingham]],<ref>[http://www.birminghamsciencecity.co.uk/about-us/ About Us at Birmingham Science City]</ref> [[Bristol]], [[York]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]]<ref>[http://www.ncl.ac.uk/about/values/partnerships/civic/sciencecity.htm Newcastle Science City] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717002747/http://www.ncl.ac.uk/about/values/partnerships/civic/sciencecity.htm |date=17 July 2011 }}</ref> and [[Manchester]].
==Structure== It is [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/318420 situated] in former [[BASF]] buildings, which previously were used by Boots as research laboratories.
The [https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/948642 site] on ''[https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1899769 Pennyfoot Street]'', between the [[A60 road|A60]] and [[A612 road|A612]], is for bioscience [[Small and medium enterprises|SME]]s. The University of Nottingham has the largest collaboration with companies at BioCity, with a few having links with NTU.
There are three buildings – * Innovation Centre Building * Stewart Adams Building – named after Dr Stewart Adams OBE, who led the team at Boots (with John Nicholson) that discovered Ibuprofen, a [[non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug]], in 1963<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/3351540/Dr-Stewart-Adams-I-tested-ibuprofen-on-my-hangover.html Dr Stewart Adams]</ref> * Laurus Building
In January 2012 BioCity opened a second site, BioCity Scotland, resulting from the acquisition of a former MSD research facility near Glasgow.
==See also== * [[Sheffield Bioincubator]] * [[London Bioscience Innovation Centre]] * [[Francis Crick Institute]] * [[Creative Quarter, Nottingham]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.biocity.co.uk BioCity Nottingham] * [http://www.science-city.co.uk Science City Nottingham] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100826235831/http://www.ukspa.org.uk/science_parks/content/1116/biocity_nottingham UKSPA] * [http://www.ntu.ac.uk/sat/business/centres/biocity.html NTU] * [https://www.cpmg-architects.com/architecture/projects/biocity-discovery-building CPMG Architects - Discovery Building at BioCity]
===News items=== * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/nottinghamshire/7645283.stm Laurus Building opens in October 2008]
===Video clips=== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GO4-gaKigCY Glen Crocker] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RMXOfuz0La0 Invest Nottingham] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZhUuQAKFg4c Nottingham Science – Laurus Building]
